deck: The lone soldier that descended into the depths of Hell and went insane.
description:
Origin

The Doom Marine was stationed on Mars and was ordered to go to Phobos after the UAC experiments had caused an invasion of demons. He killed nearly the whole demon army, and reached the teleporter to Deimos. The Marine eventually faced off against the massive Cyberdemon, the guardian of the Tower of Babel, and defeated him. He would later encounter the Spider Mastermind and destroy him. The final boss, Icon of Sin, is an immense baphomet that the Marine defeats at the end of Doom II.

Creation

Created by id Software, the Doom Marine had no name, as it wasn't necessary. John Carmack and John Romero were one of his creators.

Major Story Arcs

Knee Deep In The Dead!

The Doom comic starts with the Doom Marine going insane from using a berserker pack and ripping out the spine of an Imp. He goes on to encounter the massive Cyberdemon who he punches and retreats to look for a gun. The marine faces off against the Zombies and Cacodemons, getting the Shotgun and Chainsaw in the process. He then encounters a Demon and then a Spectre, and gets a hold of the Chaingun and Plasma Rifle.

The marine finally finds the ultimate weapon, the BFG-9000 past an all-out demon brawl. Barons, Revenants, Zombies all tearing apart each other, the marine finally gets the BFG and goes off to face the Cyberdemon. The Doom Marine dodges the giant demon's attacks and fires the BFG, destroying the Cyberdemon at last.

Weapons

  • Chainsaw
  • Pistol
  • Shotgun
  • Super Shotgun
  • Chaingun
  • Rocket Launcher
  • Plasma Rifle
  • BFG-9000

Other Media

Doom

He killed nearly the whole demon army, and reached the teleporter to Deimos. The Marine eventually faced off against the massive Cyberdemon, the guardian of the Tower of Babel, and defeated him. Created by id Software.

Doom II

The forces of Hell invades Earth and it is up to the Doom Marine to destroy the invasion and defeat the Icon of Sin.

name: Doom Marine

deck: Cousin of the Baron of Hell, they're slightly easier to kill, but tend to appear in larger numbers.
description:
Overview

Doom II

Introduced in Doom II, the Hell Knight monster is considered a weaker cousin of the Baron of Hell. They possess a slightly different appearance and are not as tough as the Barons, but its attacks are just as potent, making them a legitimate threat nonetheless.

The Doom II manual describes the Hell Knight as "Tough as a dump truck and nearly as big, these Goliaths are the worst things on two legs since Tyrannosaurus rex." In the manual for the original Doom however, this was the description used for the Baron of Hell. The Official DOOM FAQ instead describes the Hell Knights as "Slightly easier to kill than our friend the Baron, but appear in larger numbers."

Doom 3

The Hell Knights in Doom 3 are essentially a fusion of Hell Knights and Barons of Hell, as the Barons are otherwise absent from the game. These Hell Knights are tougher than their past incarnation, and look considerably more alien and less like a minotaur or satyr. Taller, more muscular, and significantly more gruesome looking, the Doom 3 Hell Knight is far from a pushover.

Powers & Abilities

Hell Knights attack by clawing at an opponent when close or from a distance by throwing comet-like fireballs, much like the Barons of Hell. In Doom 3, the Hell Knights are almost as tough as the Barons were and also posses a nasty bite attack for close combat.

Other Media

Doom (2005)

The Hell Knight makes its share of appearances in the 2005 Doom movie. It isn't able to shoot fireballs, but it does wield a high-tech chainsaw at one point.
name: Hell Knight

deck: The Mech-Monster was created by Lord Maur-Kon's techno-mages to battle the Shogun Warriors.
description:
The Mech-Monster was initially a mechanized, reptilian monster created by Lord Maur-Kon and his techno-mages. Lord Maur-Kon wanted to employ science into his creation because the monsters created by magic and sorcery were being defeated by the Shogun Warriors. However, one of Maur-Kon's lieutenants named Magar believed the old, ancient way was more superior than science and dubbed his leader a traitor. Magar stole the device that controlled the Mech-Monster after a demonstration and placed it inside the sacred pool of dark life. The Mech-Monster emerged from the molten earth instilled with magical life and was more organic than machine.

CreationÂ 

The Mech-Monster was created by Doug Moench and Herb Trimpe in 1979 and first appeared in Shogun Warriors # 3.Â
name: Mech-Monster
